newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korean opposition blasts "pompous" president.
newsitem.headline: S.Korean opposition blasts "pompous" president.

text.p: South Korea's main opposition leader Kim Dae-jung on Friday blasted President Kim Young-sam's vague apology over financial abuses as "pompous and confrontational" and said he had hard evidence of wrongdoing.
He vowed a head-on fight with the president to uncover the truth behind his spending on the 1992 presidential election campaign.

Kim Dae-jung, who heads the National Congress for New Politics, alleged President Kim received 300 billion won ($336 million) from his predecessor Roh Tae-woo and 60 billion won from the scandal-ridden Hanbo Group.
The spending limit for candidates in the 1992 elections, in which Kim Dae-jung was defeated, was 36.7 billion won.
"I have evidence and witnesses, but they cannot come forward yet," the opposition firebrand told a news conference.
Roh is serving a 17-year jail term for corruption and other crimes while in office. The Hanbo Group is at the centre of a bribery scandal engulfing Kim Young-sam's own presidency.

"His gesture, tone of voice, and the content of his speech were pompous and confrontational," said Kim Dae-jung, elected by his party last week to be its standard-bearer in presidential elections in December.
"President Kim's attitude has disappointed the Korean people."

President Kim apologised in a live national television broadcast for "past wrongdoings" by himself and others. But he refused to give any specifics and suggested his opponents were just as guilty. He also promised reform.

"I know the president is smart. Why would he not remember receiving money from Roh Tae-woo and Hanbo?" asked Kim Dae-jung, whose intense rivalry with the president has overshadowed South Korean politics for several decades.
"He should not use threatening words and gestures when apologising to the people," he said.
Kim Dae-jung was referring to the president's unexplained warning that he would make a "grave decision" if the opposition scuttled efforts to implement reform.
"That sounds ridiculous," said Kim Dae-jung. "The president has the responsibility, and the power, to revise legislation if he wants.

"We cannot tolerate this any more. We have decided to fight the president directly," he said, adding his party would demand an independent probe by the National Assembly and call on the president to testify.
However, Kim Dae-jung said there were no immediate plans to call on the president to step down.
"It's a very important issue, which we must further discuss with the United Liberal Democrats," he said, referring to a much smaller opposition group.
He said it would be impossible to rally support in parliament for moves to impeach the president since the ruling New Korea Party held a majority in the National Assembly.
Kim Young-sam's single term expires in February next year.

Asked about his own election funding, Kim Dae-jung said: "Kim Young-sam used so much he doesn't know how much he used. But we are are poor and we know exactly how much we spent." He put his own spending at 20.7 billion won. ($1 =892 won)
